multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 shows a standard tube near a crossing ball C<sub>t</sub>. Which of the following statements is **incorrect** regarding the arcs α<sub>1</sub>, α<sub>2</sub> associated with a crossing tube near C<sub>t</sub>?
choices: For r=1,2, there is an isotopy of (α<sub>r</sub>,∂α<sub>r</sub>) through (S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup>\F, S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup>∩∂ν<sub>L</sub>) to (∂C<sub>t</sub>, S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup>∩∂ν<sub>L</sub>∩∂C<sub>t</sub>).
For r=1,2, α<sub>r</sub> is parallel through S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup> to C<sub>t</sub>, allowing the endpoints to slide along S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup>∩∂ν<sub>L</sub>
The endpoints of α<sub>1</sub>, α<sub>2</sub> are also endpoints of the four arcs of F∩∂ν<sub>L</sub>∩S<sup>±</sup> that traverse the overpass and underpass at C<sub>t</sub>.

The endpoints of α<sub>1</sub> and α<sub>2</sub> are (among) the points of F∩∂ν<sub>L</sub>∩S<sup>+</sup>∩S<sup>−</sup> **farthest** from C<sub>t</sub> in each of the four directions along ∂ν<sub>L</sub>.
